Converting CO2 from the coal chemical industry into natural gas via methanation reaction, coupled with green hydrogen, is a promising strategy for reducing carbon emissions. While Ni-based catalysts are cost-effective and widely used for CO2 methanation, their performance is often hindered by low temperatures activity. We confined LaOx species within the mesoporous silica (mSiO2) channels to serve as a support for Ni-based CO2 methanation catalysts. The results demonstrate that LaOx introduction (3.9 wt%) significantly improves CO2 conversion from 38.2 % to 74.4 %, while enhancing CH4 selectivity from 94.8 % to 99.7 % at 300 °C. Interestingly, excessive La loading does not noticeably reduce the promotion efficiency. Detailed characterization revealed that ultrafine LaOx species anchored within silica framework improved the dispersion and reduction of Ni nanoparticles and served as strong basic sites to promote CO2 dissociation. In-situ DRIFT and isotope studies demonstrated that LaOx facilitated the hydrogenation of formate intermediates, enhancing both CO2 conversion and CH4 selectivity. In addition, LaOx endowed the support with hydrogen spillover capability, enabling active H from Ni nanoparticles to migrate to LaOx sites and accelerate the conversion of formate intermediates into CH4. These results underscore the potential of LaOx-modified mesoporous silica to optimize Ni-based catalysts, offering valuable guidance for the design of high-performance CO2 hydrogenation catalyst supports. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords CO2 methanation Ni nanoparticles LaOx species promoter Mesoporous silica CO2 conversion and utilization Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Green hydrogen coupling in the coal chemical and petrochemical industries, which converts generated CO2 into methane for injection into natural gas pipelines, is a promising strategy for reducing carbon emissions [1]. However, this process involves the reduction of fully oxidized carbon to methane, which requires an eight-electron transfer and faces significant kinetic limitations [2]. An effective catalyst is therefore essential to achieve a favorable reaction rate with high methane selectivity. The CO2 methanation reaction is most efficient at lower temperatures (≤ 300 °C), as the reaction is highly exothermic and lower temperatures enhance CO2 conversion efficiency [3]. Thus, the development of efficient catalysts is central to advancing this process. Ni-based catalysts are widely regarded as the most promising active metals for CO2 methanation due to their exceptional catalytic activity, high CH4 selectivity, and low cost [4]. However, Ni catalysts suffer from poor low-temperature activity [5]. Sterk et al. [6] utilized density functional theory (DFT) calculations to reveal that the (111), (100), and (211) facets of Ni nanoparticles lack the activity for CO2 hydrogenation to CO, while only the (110) facet being capable of catalyzing CO2 hydrogenation to CH4. In this process, the dissociation of formate intermediates is identified as the rate-determining step. Consequently, Ni/SiO2 [7], Ni/Al2O3 [8], Ni/AC [9], and Ni/CNTs [10] catalysts exhibit poor low-temperature activity and high CO selectivity during CO2 hydrogenation. In contrast, catalysts such as Ni/CeO2 [11], Ni/MgO [12], Ni/CeZrO4 [13], Ni/Y2O3 [14] demonstrate excellent catalytic performance for CO2 methanation, achieving nearly 100 % CH4 selectivity across a wide temperature range. This superior performance is attributed to their CO2 activation sites, modulate metal-support interactions, and alter reaction pathways. These findings offer valuable insights for designing CO2 methanation catalysts using widely available industrial catalyst support materials. The addition of promoters such as CeO2, La2O3, and MnO2 to Ni-based CO2 methanation catalysts has been extensively studied, showing significant enhancement in catalytic performance [8,15,16]. Previously, we discovered that incorporating an appropriate amount of CeO2 into mesoporous silica significantly enhances the CO2 conversion rate and CH4 selectivity [7]. However, excessive addition of CeO2 not only diminishes this promotional effect but can even lead to a negative impact. A similar trend is observed with the use of Mn additives [17]. This limits the use of these additives because of the inevitable segregation in the catalyst and the possibility of the additives ripening during the use of the catalyst. Rare earth metals, such as La and Ce, have similar valence electron configurations, atomic radius as well as the chemical structures, which are wildly used as additives in Ni-based CO2 methanation catalysts. Unlike CeO2, which exhibits excellent reducibility due to its redox cycling between Ce4+ and Ce3+, La2O₃ is considered a non-reducible oxide with a high energy barrier for oxygen vacancy formation (∼6 eV) [18,19]. La2O₃ also has stronger basicity but weaker metal-support interactions compared to CeO2. Additionally, La2O₃ displays lower thermal and chemical stability, as it readily reacts with CO2 and H2O to form La2(CO3)3 under reaction conditions. These characteristics make lanthanum less predictable than cerium as a catalyst promoter. Consequently, despite its similar cost to CeO2 and its potential for superior catalytic performance, La2O3 has received significantly less attention than CeO2 in catalyst design. In this study, we confined highly dispersed LaOx within the mesoporous channels of silica to serve as the support for Ni-based CO2 methanation catalysts. Compared to our previous work using highly dispersed CeOx anchored in mesoporous silica [8], LaOx exhibited superior CO2 conversion rates at low temperatures. Even a small amount of La addition increased CH4 selectivity to over 99.5 %, while an optimal loading of La achieved excellent results in both CO2 conversion and CH4 selectivity. Importantly, excessive La loading did not diminish the promotional effect, unlike what is often observed with CeO2. These findings indicate that La is potentially more effective than Ce as a promoter for Ni-based CO2 methanation catalysts. The composition and structure of the support and catalyst were systematically characterized using XRD, HR-TEM, XPS, N2 adsorption, and H2-TPR techniques. Reaction kinetics and temperature-programmed surface reaction tests highlighted the multifunctional role of LaOx in improving catalyst structure. In-situ DRIFT spectroscopy and isotope labeling experiments elucidated the critical role of LaOx in accelerating the rate-determining step of the reaction mechanism. This study provides an important paradigm for employing LaOx as a promoter and designing efficient low-temperature, highly active CO2 methanation catalysts. 2 Material and methods 2.1 Catalyst preparation LaOx-decorated mesoporous silica (mSiO2) was synthesized with a template-free technique and a one-pot method. In a typical synthesis, 21.22 g tetraethyl orthosilicate (TEOS, 98 %, purchased from Acros Organics Company) add to 50 mL of ethanolic solution containing 0.25 g La(NO3)3·6H2O (99 %, purchased from aladdin Company) to obtain the solution A. Solution B is prepared by mixing 15.33 g triethanolamine (TEA, 97 %, purchased from Acros Organics Company) and 11.53 g distilled water. Then, solution B is added dropwise to solution A and stirred for 30 min, followed by 21.90 g tetraethyl ammonium hydroxide (TEAOH, 25 wt% in water, purchased from Acros Organics Company). Afterwards, the solution was stirred at room temperature until uniformity gel was obtained. Then the gel was dried under 110 °C for 24 h, then placed in an autoclave for the following hydrothermal treatment at 180 °C for 3 h. The material obtained was calcined at 600 °C for 8 h with a ramp of 2 °C∙min-1. The sample after calcination is abbreviated as La-mSiO2–100. The same procedure was used to synthesize other samples with different Si/La molar ratios or without lanthanum. These samples are indicated as La-mSiO2-x, where "x = 300, 200, 100, 50, 25" represents the Si/La molar ratio. The Ni was supported over mSiO2 and La-mSiO2-x by incipient wetness impregnation. Typically, 0.8426 g of the Ni(NO3)2·6H2O (98 %) was dissolved in a 50 vol% ethanol aqueous solution was impregnate to 1.5 g of the support. After impregnation, the catalyst was aged at room temperature for 4 h, dried at 100 °C overnight, and then calcined at 350 °C for 2 h in flowing air. 2.2 Catalyst characterization Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were recorded on an X'pert-Pro diffractometer (PANalytical, Netherlands) using Cu Kα radiation (40 kV, 40 mA) over the range of 10°−80° with a step size of 0.2°. Post-reaction and reduction, the catalysts were collected in an inert atmosphere and immediately analyzed. The N2 adsorption-desorption experiments were carried out on a Micromeritics ASAP 2020 Plus apparatus at −196 °C. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was conducted on a Thermo Scientific K-Alpha spectrometer using a monochromatic Al Kα X-ray beam (1486.6 eV, 12 kV, 6 mA). Binding energies were calibrated to the C 1s peak of adventitious carbon at 284.8 eV. Scanning Electron Microscopy (SEM) was performed on a JEOL 7800F microscope at an accelerating voltage of 10 kV, while high-resolution Transmission Electron Microscopy (HR-TEM) analysis was carried out using a phase-corrected electron microscope (Titan Themis G3 ETEM, Thermo Fisher Scientific). Temperature-programmed experiments were conducted in a fixed-bed quartz U-tube reactor (inner diameter: 6 mm) monitored by mass spectrometry (Pfeiffer GCD 320). The signals of H2 (m/z = 2), CH4 (m/z = 15, 16), CO (m/z = 28), and CO2 (m/z = 44, 28) were recorded. H2-TPR: Catalysts were pretreated at 200 °C in Ar flow, followed by H2-TPR analysis from room temperature to 800 °C at a heating rate of 10 °C∙min⁻¹ under a 5 % H2/Ar flow (40 mL∙min⁻¹). CO2-TPD: Reduced samples were exposed to CO2 at 50 °C for 1 h, flushed with Ar, and heated from 50 °C to 800 °C at 10 °C∙min⁻¹. A similar procedure was followed for H2-TPD using H2 as the adsorbate. H2-D2 exchange experiments were conducted by introducing 10 % H2/10 % D2/80 % Ar into a pre-reduced catalyst (350 °C, 2 h) and ramping the temperature to 200 °C at 10 °C∙min⁻¹. Signals for H2 (m/z = 2), D2 (m/z = 4), and HD (m/z = 3) were recorded. H2-TPSR profiles were obtained after CO2 adsorption at 50 °C for 1 h, followed by flushing with Ar and heating from 50 °C to 800 °C under 5 % H2/Ar flow at 10 °C∙min⁻¹. Hydrogen spillover-induced WO3 color change was assessed by mixing 5 mg of reduced catalyst with 1000 mg of WO3, heating at 180 °C under H2 flow (40 mL∙min⁻¹) for 10 min. In-situ DRIFTS detected the adsorption and dissociation of reactants by catalysts on VERTEX 80 V (Bruker). Prior to the experiment, the catalyst was reduced at 350 °C for 2 h under 40 mL·min-1 H2 and subsequently purged with Ar for 30 min. The reaction gas is 5 % CO2+20 % H2+80 % Ar, H2 and Ar are high purity. Spectra were obtained at intervals of 60 s by collecting 32 scans with a resolution of 4 cm-1. 2.3 Evaluation of CO2 methanation performances CO2 methanation was performed in a three-channel fixed-bed reactor housed in a temperature-controlled oven. 100 mg of calcined catalyst (160–400 μm) was mixed with 1.00 g of quartz sand (300–400 μm) and loaded into a quartz tube (ID: 8 mm). Catalysts were pre-reduced at 350 °C for 2 h in 40 mL∙min⁻¹ H2 flow before cooling to 180 °C in Ar. The feed gas (19 % CO2/76 % H2/5 % N2) was introduced, and outlet gases were analyzed using an online gas chromatograph (Agilent 7890B). CO2 conversion (XCO2, %), CH4 selectivity (SCH4, %) and CH4 formation rate (RCH4, μmol·gcat. - 1·h-1) were calculated as follows: (1) C O 2 c o n v e r s i o n ( % ) = F C O 2 , i n − F C O 2 , o u t F C O 2 , i n × 100 % (2) C H 4 s e l e c t i v i t y ( % ) = F C H 4 , o u t F C O 2 , i n × 100 % (3) C O 2 r e a c t i o n r a t e ( μ m o l g − 1 mi n − 1 ) = F C O 2 , i n − F C O 2 , o u t m c a t . where F and mcat. are the molar flow rate and the sample weight, respectively. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Preparation and characteristics of LaOx-decorated mesopores silica LaOx -decorated mesoporous silica (La-mSiO2-x, x = 300, 200, 100, 50, 25) was synthesized using TEOS as Si source, TEA and TEAOH as pore formers, and La(NO3)3·6H2O as La source (Fig. 1 a). Typical La-mSiO2–50 sample exhibits an irregular block structure with a sponge-like rough surface and porous structure (Fig. 1 b). From the EDS elemental mapping images, it can be observed that La is uniformly distributed in mSiO2 (Fig. 1 c–f). The texture properties of mSiO2 and La-mSiO2-x materials were characterized by N2 adsorption-desorption experiment. As is shown in Fig. 1 g and Fig. S1, all samples present typical IV isotherms with an H1-type hysteresis loop, suggest thus mesoporous with a “cylindrical” pore shape and narrow pore size distribution between 2 and 8 nm [20]. The prepared mesoporous materials show a high specific surface area ranging from 574 to 704 m2⋅g-1 with an average pore size of 3.2 to 4.1 nm. After La doping, the specific surface area increases slightly and the average pore size decreases. LaOx doping decrease pore size and increase the surface area. Similar phenomenon was also found in the synthesis of other mesoporous silicas, such as La doped zeolite [21,22]. Composition and textural properties of the prepared samples are reported in Table 1 . The crystal structures of mSiO2 and La-mSiO2-x (x = 100, 50, 25) materials were analyzed by XRD. As depicted in Fig. S2, no distinct diffraction peaks are observed except for a broad peak ranging from 15° to 30°, corresponding to amorphous SiO2. This pattern remains consistent regardless of the Si/La ratio. The absence of diffraction peaks corresponding to La2O3 and other La-containing species suggests either a high dispersion of La2O3 or an amorphous structure of these materials, even at a high La loading of up to approximately 8.3 wt% (Table 1). 3.2 Nanostructure and properties of catalysts Ni supported on mSiO2 and La-mSiO2-x (x = 100, 50, 25) catalysts were prepared using the incipient wetness impregnation method. The catalysts exhibit a sponge-like structure, as observed from SEM images of La-mSiO2–50. EDS elemental mapping confirms the uniform distribution of Ni and La on the Ni/La-mSiO2–50 catalyst Fig. S3. All catalysts showed type IV N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms, which were the same as those of the supports Fig. S4a [23]. TEM image of the reduced Ni/La-mSiO2–50 catalysts, along with metallic Ni particle size distribution histograms, are shown in Fig. 2 a. Ni nanoparticles are uniformly dispersed both within and on the external surfaces of the pores. Fig. 2 b display FFT images of Ni/mSiO2 and Ni/La-mSiO2–50, revealing lattice spacings of 0.20, 0.18, and 0.13 nm, corresponding to the (111), (200), and (220) planes of metallic Ni, respectively. This confirms that NiO was completely reduced to metallic Ni, with no La2O2 nanoparticles detected. The average particle sizes for Ni/La-mSiO2–50 were determined to be 7.3 ± 1.7 nm (Fig. 2 c). Compared with the previously reported Ni/mSiO2 prepared by similar method, LaOx can promote the dispersion of Ni nanoparticles [7]. HR-TEM image further corroborate these findings (Fig. 2 d). The Ni/La-mSiO2–50 catalyst exhibits lattice fringes with a 0.18 nm spacing at right angles, corresponding to the (200) plane of metallic Ni. No lattice fringes or diffraction spots for La2O3 were observed, indicating that LaOx is highly dispersed within the mSiO2 framework. XRD patterns of calcined catalysts are displayed in Fig. S5. Besides the broad peak at 15–30°, characteristic of the amorphous support, four diffraction peaks at 37.2°, 43.2°, 62.9°, and 75.4° corresponding to the (111), (200), (220), and (311) planes of NiO (PDF #47–1049) were observed. For the reduced catalysts, peaks at 44.5°, 51.8°, and 76.4°, corresponding to the (111), (200), and (220) planes of metallic Ni (PDF #47–1049), confirm that NiO was fully reduced (Fig. 3 ). Using the Scherrer formula, the crystallite size of Ni nanoparticles was calculated, showing a reduction in size from 6.6 nm for Ni/La-mSiO2–100 to 5.3 nm for Ni/La-mSiO2–50, consistent with both the HR-TEM observations and H2-chemisorption results of improved Ni dispersion by La doping (Table 2 ). The surface composition and electronic properties of the reduced catalysts were analyzed using XPS. Fig. 4 a shows the La 3d5/2 spectra for Ni/mSiO2 and Ni/La-mSiO2-x (x = 100, 50, 25). The binding energy of La 3d5/2 ranged from 835.5 to 836.0 eV, which is higher than the reported values for pure La2O3 or La2(CO3)3 (834.3–835.0 eV) [10,24]. Deconvolution of the La 3d spectra revealed a binding energy gap of ∼3.5 eV, indicative of the high oxidation state of ultrafine LaOx species [25,26]. This shift suggests significant electron transfer from La to the SiO2 framework. Fig. 4 b displays the Ni 2p3/2 XPS spectra, which were deconvoluted into peaks corresponding to Ni0 (852.1 eV), NiO (853.7 eV), Ni(OH)2 (856.1 eV), and a satellite peak (861.1 eV) (Table S1) [27]. The introduction of La increased the proportion of NiO, with its content rising from 15.8 % to 26.9 % as the Si/La ratio decreased from 100 to 25. This suggests that La doping promotes the reduction of Ni species [28]. The O 1s spectrum of the reduced catalyst can be divided into two peaks, of which the peak at 532.9 eV belongs to the SiO2 species, and the peak at 530.3 eV belongs to the peak of metal oxides, including NiO and LaOx species (Fig. S6a). La doping does not change the electronic structure of the O species in the SiO2 species. The Si 2p XPS spectrum can only be fitted into a pair of peaks of SiO2, located at 103.5 eV (Fig. S6b). La doping does not cause a significant change in the position of the Si 2p peak. H2-TPR was employed to evaluate the reducibility and metal-support interactions of the catalysts (Fig. 5 ). Ni/mSiO2 exhibited two reduction peaks at 435 °C and 555 °C, corresponding to Ni species with weak and strong interactions with the support, respectively [29]. After LaOx was introduced, the peak corresponding to weakly interacting Ni species (β) shifted to a lower temperature (∼388 °C), indicating weakened metal-support interactions. However, excessive LaOx doping shifted the strong interaction peak (γ) to higher temperatures, suggesting that excessive LaOx increases the interaction strength. A new reduction peak (α) around 220 °C was observed in La-doped catalysts, with its intensity increasing as the La doping content increased. This peak is attributed to the NiO nanoparticles interaction with La2O3, suggesting that La2O3 facilitates the reduction of NiO by enhancing the reducibility of the catalyst [30,31]. 3.3 CO2 methanation activity The catalytic performance of the prepared Ni/mSiO2 and Ni/La-mSiO2-x (x = 300, 200, 100, 50, 25) catalysts for CO2 methanation was evaluated under a weight hourly space velocity (WHSV) of 24,000 mL·gcat -1·h-1, with a H2/CO2 = 4, in the temperature range of 180 – 400 °C. As is shown in Fig. 6 a, none of the catalysts reached equilibrium conversion under the tested conditions, while CO2 conversion plateaued above 360 °C. Ni/mSiO2 has better catalyst performance than Ni/SiO2 at the same temperature. Furthermore, adding La can significantly improve the CO2 conversion rate. At 300 °C, the CO2 conversion for Ni/mSiO2 was 38.3 %, while that for Ni/La-mSiO2–50 reached 74.4 %, representing a two-fold improvement in CO2 conversion. As shown in Fig. 6 b, within the tested temperature range, CH4 selectivity increased from 95.0 % to over 99.5 %, indicating that La doping significantly enhances CH4 selectivity. In industrial applications, CO2 methanation typically requires lower operating temperatures, often ≤300 °C. Fig. 6 c illustrates the impact of different La doping levels on CO2 conversion and CH4 selectivity at 300 °C. When the Si/La ratio was 300, the CO2 conversion did not increase significantly compared to Ni/mSiO2. The optimal performance was achieved with a Si/La ratio of 50. Moreover, the CO2 conversion rate remains largely unaffected even when the Si/La ratio is reduced to 25. This stands in contrast to previous studies, which have demonstrated that excessive addition of CeO2 to Ni-based catalysts can significantly impair the catalytic activity [7]. Notably, even small amounts of La doping markedly improved CH4 selectivity. With a Si/La ratio of 300 (0.69 wt% La doping), CH4 selectivity increased from 94.8 % to 99.5 %. These results demonstrate that La doping significantly enhances the selectivity for the target product, methane. Fig. 6 d shows the Arrhenius plots of the catalysts. La doping reduced the activation energy of CO2 hydrogenation from 83.3 kJ·mol-1 to 73.9 kJ·mol-1, indicating that La lowers the energy barrier for the reaction. Although Ni/mSiO2 and Ni/La-mSiO2–50 catalysts were designed with thermally treated interfaces, their stability under the reductive conditions of CO2 hydrogenation was also evaluated. As shown in Fig. 6 e, both catalysts exhibited excellent stability at 300 °C. While sintering has been reported to deactivate similar catalysts [32], no significant deactivation was observed under these conditions. The structure of the catalyst after the reaction was studied by XRD. As shown in Figure S7, the catalyst after use showed characteristic diffraction peaks at 44.5°, 51.8°, and 76.4° belonging to metal Ni, and no diffraction peaks belonging to species such as LaOx appeared, which was like the reduced catalysts. The crystallite size of Ni was estimated by the Scherrer formula. As shown in Table S2, the crystallite size of Ni in the catalyst after the reaction was about 5.8–7.2 nm. Compared with the sample after reduction, the increase of Ni nanoparticles was <1 nm, indicating that Ni did not undergo obvious sintering in the reaction test at 200–400 °C. 3.3 CO2 adsorption and activation The adsorption and activation of CO2 on the catalyst were investigated using CO2-TPD and TPSR analyses. Ni/mSiO2 and Ni/La-mSiO2–50 were selected to examine the effect of LaOx species doping. The mass spectra signals for CO (m/z = 28) and CO2 (m/z = 44) in the CO2-TPD experiments are shown in Fig. 7 a. The CO2 desorption profile can be categorized into three types of basic sites: weak basic sites (T < 200 °C), moderate basic sites (200 °C – 400 °C), and strong basic sites (T > 400 °C) [7,33]. Both Ni/mSiO2 and Ni/La-mSiO2–50 catalysts exhibited one weak basic site and two moderate basic sites. The weak basic site is attributed to CO2 adsorption on hydroxyl groups of SiO2 [34], while the moderate basic sites originate from CO2 adsorption on Ni-NiO acid-base pairs. After LaOx was introduced, the CO2 desorption peaks corresponding to the moderate basic sites shifted to lower temperatures, indicating that La doping weakens the CO2 adsorption strength on Ni nanoparticles. Notably, a strong basic site with a desorption peak at 501 °C appeared in Ni/La-mSiO2–50, attributed to CO2 adsorption on LaOx. This result highlights the high activity of LaOx in CO2 dissociation. Such strong basic sites were also found when doping Ce, but the CeO2 basic sites can be activated without Ni [7]. Further experiments involving CO2 pre-adsorption followed by H2 introduction revealed that La doping significantly reduces the temperature required for CH4 formation (Fig. 7 b). In addition, compared to Ni/mSiO2, the La-doped catalyst produced less CO. The TPSR curve of Ni/La-mSiO2–50 also showed a CO2 desorption peak and a CO generation peak above 500 °C, suggesting that some CO2 was strongly adsorbed onto the catalyst, which hindered the reaction. 3.7 H2 activation and H spillover To further investigate the catalyst's ability to dissociate and transport H2 and to determine whether H2 dissociation is the rate-determining step in the reaction, H-D exchange, WO3 color change, and D2 kinetic isotope effect (D2-KIE) experiments were conducted. The H-D exchange data are shown in Fig. 8 a. Ni/mSiO2 exhibited a higher HD generation signal at room temperature. However, the La-doped catalyst showed a higher HD generation rate at 150 °C, indicating that La doping reduces the H2 dissociation activity of the catalyst. Hydrogen spillover on the catalyst was examined using WO3 as a probe. As shown in Fig. 8 b, after treating a mixture of reduced Ni/La-mSiO2–50 and WO3 at 180 °C for 10 min, WO3 turned blue. This color change is attributed to H2 dissociated on Ni nanoparticles spilling over to the catalyst support and WO3, leading to partial reduction of WO3 [26]. In contrast, a mixture of Ni/mSiO2 and WO3 showed no color change under the same conditions, similar to the control WO3-only sample. These results indicate that La doping imparts hydrogen spillover capability to mSiO2, enabling H2 transport from Ni nanoparticles to LaOx sites, thereby enhancing catalytic performance. To determine whether H2 dissociation is the rate-determining step in CO2 hydrogenation, the D2-KIE of the catalysts was evaluated. As shown in Fig. 8 c, the kH2/kD2 ratios for Ni/mSiO2 and Ni/La-mSiO2–50 were 0.95 and 1.15, respectively. The CO2 hydrogenation reaction rates with H2 and D2 were <1.4 times different, indicating an insignificant kinetic isotope effect. This suggests that H2 dissociation is not the rate-determining step in the CO2 hydrogenation process. 3.6 In-situ DRIFTS Three primary reaction pathways for CO2 methanation have been reported in the literature: the formate pathway, the carbide pathway, and the carbonyl pathway [3]. The identification of the dominant reaction mechanism relies on monitoring key intermediates, including formate (COOH*), carbonate (CO3*), and CO* [1]. To achieve this, in-situ DRIFTS (Diffuse Reflectance Infrared Fourier Transform spectroscopy) was employed under CO2 hydrogenation conditions. As shown in Fig. 9 a, introducing the reaction mixture to reduced Ni/La-mSiO2–50 led to the observation of trifold-CO* (t-CO*, 1878 cm-1) [7]. This signal indicates that t-CO* originates from the direct dissociation of CO2, confirming the presence of the carbide pathway [35]. Similar CO* signals were also detected in Ce doped catalyst at 20 °C. In addition to CO formed via the carbide pathway, Ni/La-mSiO2–50 exhibited signals corresponding to bicarbonate (HCO3*, 1630 cm⁻¹) and monodentate carbonate (b-CO3*, 1490 and 1401 cm⁻¹) under CO2 hydrogenation conditions. These species arise from the reaction of CO2 with surface hydroxyl groups. Fig. 9 b further illustrates the in-situ DRIFT spectra of the catalysts under CO2 hydrogenation conditions. A formate band at 1592 cm⁻¹ emerged in Ni/mSiO2 when the reaction temperature exceeded 100 °C. Additionally, a bridged CO* (b-CO*) band at 1944 cm⁻¹ appeared above 150 °C, while gaseous CO (2143 cm⁻¹) was detected starting at 250 °C. The emergence of the formate band at 1592 cm⁻¹ confirms that the formate pathway is active, which is associated with higher CH4 selectivity compared to the carbide route [36]. Previous studies by reported that oxygen vacancies facilitate the formation of bidentate carbonates, which have a lower energy barrier for formate generation compared to monodentate carbonates [35]. The in-situ DRIFTS analysis of CO2 under reaction conditions confirms that both the formate pathway and the carbide pathway are active on Ni/La-mSiO2–50 catalyst. However, after La doping, the formation of formate requires higher temperatures due to the reduced H2 dissociation rate. To investigate the mechanism by how the La doping enhances CO2 methanation rate, the reaction gas (CO2/H2) was switched to Ar. As shown in Fig. 9 c, after switching to Ar, the intensities of b-CO* and t-CO* on the Ni/La-mSiO2–50, both the CO* and formate signals diminished more rapidly. Additionally, as shown in Fig. S8, CH4 production behavior differed significantly between the two catalysts. On Ni/mSiO2, CH4 rapidly disappeared after switching to Ar. Conversely, on Ni/La-mSiO2–50, CH4 levels decreased much more slowly. This indicates that formate on Ni/La-mSiO2–50 can continue to undergo hydrogenation to produce CH4 even in the absence of a continuous supply of CO2 and H2. This is different from the cases without additives and with Ce addition, where H2 is required to drive the reaction forward [7]. In summary, La doping facilitates the conversion of formate into CH4, thereby enhancing the overall reaction rate. Huang et al. [37] demonstrated via DFT calculations that the generation and conversion of formate in the formate pathway are the rate-determining steps of CO2 methanation. The accelerated formate conversion observed with La doping significantly increases CO2 conversion rates. The proposed reaction mechanism is illustrated in the schematic diagram in Fig. 9 d. In this mechanism, CO2 preferentially adsorbs onto LaOx, forming bidentate carbonate (b-CO3*), which undergoes hydrogenation to produce formate (HCOO*). The formate then reacts with active hydrogen on LaOx to generate CHx* species, ultimately leading to the formation of CH4. During this process, H₂ dissociates into active hydrogen atoms on Ni nanoparticles, which subsequently spillover to LaOx, facilitating the reaction. 4 Conclusion Ultrafine LaOx-modified mesoporous silica was employed as a support for Ni-catalyzed CO2 hydrogenation. The integration of LaOx enhanced the CO2 hydrogenation conversion rate by two times, achieving 38 μmol g-1 h-1 at 300 °C, and elevated the selectivity from 95 % to over 99 % at the same reaction conditions. This cost-effective, non-precious metal catalyst exhibits high catalytic activity, showcasing its promising potential applications. Structural characterization reveals that LaOx is anchored on the pore walls of mesoporous silica in a highly dispersed form. This ultrafine LaOx serves as a high-intensity CO2 dissociation active site, promoting the dissociation of CO2 into CO* and providing additional reactive sites for the reaction. Programmed temperature experiments and in situ DRIFT analyses indicate that the addition of La facilitates the carbonyl pathway, thereby significantly boosting the CO2 hydrogenation reaction rate. Furthermore, La enhances the adsorption strength of CO on the catalyst, which is crucial for improving CH4 selectivity. This study elucidates the mechanism by which highly dispersed LaOx promotes the dissociation of reactants and the conversion of intermediates in CO2 hydrogenation reactions, offering new insights for the development of high-performance CO2 methanation catalysts by using LaOx promoter. coredata.dc:description: Converting CO2 from the coal chemical industry into natural gas via methanation reaction, coupled with green hydrogen, is a promising strategy for reducing carbon emissions. While Ni-based catalysts are cost-effective and widely used for CO2 methanation, their performance is often hindered by low temperatures activity. We confined LaOx species within the mesoporous silica (mSiO2) channels to serve as a support for Ni-based CO2 methanation catalysts. The results demonstrate that LaOx introduction (3.9 wt%) significantly improves CO2 conversion from 38.2 % to 74.4 %, while enhancing CH4 selectivity from 94.8 % to 99.7 % at 300 °C. Interestingly, excessive La loading does not noticeably reduce the promotion efficiency. Detailed characterization revealed that ultrafine LaOx species anchored within silica framework improved the dispersion and reduction of Ni nanoparticles and served as strong basic sites to promote CO2 dissociation. In-situ DRIFT and isotope studies demonstrated that LaOx facilitated the hydrogenation of formate intermediates, enhancing both CO2 conversion and CH4 selectivity. In addition, LaOx endowed the support with hydrogen spillover capability, enabling active H from Ni nanoparticles to migrate to LaOx sites and accelerate the conversion of formate intermediates into CH4. These results underscore the potential of LaOx-modified mesoporous silica to optimize Ni-based catalysts, offering valuable guidance for the design of high-performance CO2 hydrogenation catalyst supports.
